name: System & Communications Protection (Monitor, control, and protect organizational communications)

items.question: SC.L1-B.1.X – Boundary Protection

Your company’s computer network needs a ‘front gate’ that monitors and protects traffic going in and out. This means using tools like firewalls (to block unwanted traffic), intrusion detection (to spot suspicious activity), and rules that control what data can flow where.

codeList.display: Your company’s computer network needs a ‘front gate’ that monitors and protects traffic going in and out. This means using tools like firewalls (to block unwanted traffic), intrusion detection (to spot suspicious activity), and rules that control what data can flow where.

items.question: What is the status of your network perimeter security (tools that control and monitor data entering or leaving your systems)?

answers.text: Fully implemented – We use firewalls and monitoring tools to control all traffic in and out of the network, and they are actively maintained.
Partially implemented – Some protections (like a firewall) are in place, but monitoring or other controls are missing or incomplete.
Not implemented – There are no firewalls or monitoring tools protecting the network.

value.text: Fully implemented – We use firewalls and monitoring tools to control all traffic in and out of the network, and they are actively maintained.

items.question: 1. System Boundary Definition

extension.valueString: Include hardware models, firmware versions and their primary functions.  e.g., Cisco ASA 5515-X v9.12.3 - Primary perimeter firewall, Palo Alto PA-220 v10.1.2 - Branch office firewall.

items.question: What systems protect the edge of your network from the outside world (e.g., internet traffic)?
items.codingInstructions: These are the tools and devices that sit at the network perimeter — like firewalls, secure gateways, or VPNs — and decide what data can come in or go out. They act as the first line of defense against hackers and unauthorized access.
items.codingInstructionsPlain: These are the tools and devices that sit at the network perimeter — like firewalls, secure gateways, or VPNs — and decide what data can come in or go out. They act as the first line of defense against hackers and unauthorized access.
items.value: Network perimeter is protected by firewalls, secure VPNs for remote access, IDS/IPS monitoring, and regular network security reviews to block unauthorized traffic.

extension.valueString: Include components that separate development, test and production environments or create internal segmentation. eg., Internal VLAN switches, host-based firewalls,  Network ACLs.

items.question: What systems protect sensitive areas inside your network from the rest of the company?
items.codingInstructions: Internal boundaries separate your most important systems from the rest of your network. For example, you may keep development systems isolated from production systems, or restrict access between employee laptops and servers holding Federal Contract Information (FCI). This limits damage if an attacker or insider gets into one part of the network.
items.codingInstructionsPlain: Internal boundaries separate your most important systems from the rest of your network. For example, you may keep development systems isolated from production systems, or restrict access between employee laptops and servers holding Federal Contract Information (FCI). This limits damage if an attacker or insider gets into one part of the network.
items.value: Sensitive areas are isolated using VLANs, internal firewalls, and role-based access controls; only authorized users and systems can access these segments, and activity is monitored.

items.codingInstructions:
Clearly define the limits of your information systems to identify what needs protection and control.

items.codingInstructions: e.g., HTTPS (TCP/443), SSH (TCP/22), DNS (UDP/53)
items.value: Examples include HTTPS (443), VPN (IPSec/SSL), and SSH (22) for administrative access; all other services are blocked by default.

items.codingInstructions: e.g., Telnet (TCP/23), FTP (TCP/21), HTTP (TCP/80)
items.value: FTP (21), and unused ports; blocked at the firewall and monitored for attempts to access.

items.question: 3. Monitoring Implementation
How do you monitor traffic crossing into or out of your company’s network?
items.codingInstructions: Monitoring at system boundaries means tracking the flow of data into and out of your network. This helps you spot unusual activity, such as unauthorized access attempts or large data transfers, using tools like firewalls, intrusion detection systems, or log reviews.

items.question: SC.L1-B.1.X – Separate Public Systems from Internal Networks

Set up a Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) or other Demilitarized Zone area for public systems. This ensures that public-facing tools are isolated from sensitive internal systems that store government contract data.

codeList.display: Set up a Demilitarized Zone (DMZ) or other Demilitarized Zone area for public systems. This ensures that public-facing tools are isolated from sensitive internal systems that store government contract data.

items.question: What is the status of separating public systems (like websites or portals) from your internal network?

answers.text: Fully implemented – Public systems are kept on their own network (DMZ or subnetwork) and fully isolated from internal systems.
Partially implemented – Some separation exists, but not all public systems are isolated.
Not implemented – Public systems are on the same network as internal systems, with no separation.

value.text: Fully implemented – Public systems are kept on their own network (DMZ or subnetwork) and fully isolated from internal systems.
